item.title: Rule of Fifty
item.description: From Nancy Pearl: >If you’re feeling lukewarm about a book, read 50 pages before deciding whether to continue or drop it. Doing this will allow you to try the books you want to read without you feeling obligated to complete them.
item.content:encoded: From Nancy Pearl: >If you’re feeling lukewarm about a book, read 50 pages before deciding whether to continue or drop it. Doing this will allow you to try the books you want to read without you feeling obligated to complete them.

item.title: Without the right tools, our minds are hopelessly leaky
Time is essential to how we remember, and should be a first-class concept in a good note-taking system
item.description: Time is essential to how we remember, and should be a first-class concept in a good note-taking system.
item.content:encoded: Time is essential to how we remember, and should be a first-class concept in a good note-taking system.

item.title: Ideas should not be lost because it took too long to capture them
Don't erase past thoughts that are now outdated, they capture your journey
a good collection of notes is like a powerful extended memory
Most of us need an external stimulus to do our best work
The value of a list is that it frees you up to think creatively
item.description: From Adam Savage The value of a list is that it frees you up to think more creatively, by defining a project’s scope and scale for you on the page, so your brain doesn’t have to hold on to so much information
item.content:encoded:
From Adam Savage

The value of a list is that it frees you up to think more creatively, by defining a project’s scope and scale for you on the page, so your brain doesn’t have to hold on to so much information

Your Brain is a Terrible Office

Resources

  • Adam Savage on Lists, More Lists, and the Power of Checkboxes WIRED

item.title: Invest in your life's goals
item.description: I have a bunch of “businesses” that compete for these resources: I’m trying to have a rewarding relationship with my wife, raise great kids, contribute to my community, succeed in my career, contribute to my church, and so on.
item.content:encoded:
I have a bunch of “businesses” that compete for these resources: I’m trying to have a rewarding relationship with my wife, raise great kids, contribute to my community, succeed in my career, contribute to my church, and so on. And I have exactly the same problem that a corporation does. I have a limited amount of time and energy and talent.

Resources

  • How Will You Measure Your Life

item.title: Curse of Knowledge
item.description: We often talk about the Curse of knowledge as a bad thing, but it’s not always bad. When thinking about this I think about this quote from Mark Cuban: Billionaire entrepreneur Mark Cuban took this a step further.
item.content:encoded:
We often talk about the Curse of knowledge as a bad thing, but it’s not always bad. When thinking about this I think about this quote from Mark Cuban:

Billionaire entrepreneur Mark Cuban took this a step further. He described growing up and loving to walk through bookstores, picking up anything that caught his eye. As he says, “30 dollars to get one idea that could propel me…it was a bargain.”

item.title: You need 10 true fans
item.description: Find ten people. Ten people who trust you/respect you/need you/listen to you… Those ten people need what you have to sell, or want it. And if they love it, you win.
item.content:encoded:
Find ten people. Ten people who trust you/respect you/need you/listen to you… Those ten people need what you have to sell, or want it. And if they love it, you win. If they love it, they’ll each find you ten more people (or a hundred or a thousand or, perhaps, just three). Repeat. If they don’t love it, you need a new product. Start over.

From First, Ten Seth’s Blog by Seth Godin

item.title: Loftie
item.description: 2022-05-09 There has been a weird phenomenon since I got the Loftie. Each night I have gone to bed before 11 and each morning I have gotten up with or before the Loftie has gone off.
item.content:encoded:
2022-05-09 There has been a weird phenomenon since I got the Loftie. Each night I have gone to bed before 11 and each morning I have gotten up with or before the Loftie has gone off. I think this has more to do with me getting good sleep than the Loftie itself, but it has been an odd experience. We also had Mother’s Day over the weekend which makes for a different dynamic than usual. I should get more representative data this week.

2022-05-07 This was my first real day with the Loftie. I got up on time, but this might not be purely due to the alarm clock. I had two drinks last night during the movie and fell asleep fairly early. More testing necessary. 😃

2022-05-06 This was my first morning with the alarm clock, but I had a unique schedule this morning with having to drop the truck off for an inspection

item.title: Analog Tools
item.description: Parent: Analog vs Digital Tools Paper is cheap. Paper is universal. Paper doesn’t run out of battery. Paper doesn’t vanish into the shadow realm when I close the window. Paper can do anything I can do with a pencil.
item.content:encoded:
Parent: Analog vs Digital Tools

Paper is cheap. Paper is universal. Paper doesn’t run out of battery. Paper doesn’t vanish into the shadow realm when I close the window. Paper can do anything I can do with a pencil. Paper lets me turn back pages in the notebook and scan over for things that have yet to be done.

Topics

  • Sacrificial List

item.title: Sacrificial List
item.description: A quick and dirty list to get you started where you don’t stress the details. The goal is to get the thoughts and ideas out of your head so that you can better evaluate them.
item.content:encoded:
A quick and dirty list to get you started where you don’t stress the details. The goal is to get the thoughts and ideas out of your head so that you can better evaluate them. Resist the urge to critique at this stage, the whole goal is to get these out of your head.

This is a great place for Analog Tools.

Adam Savage on Lists, More Lists, and the Power of Checkboxes WIRED

item.title: Use Lists to carry the knowledge and moment from this session into the next one.
item.description: Getting spun up on a topic can be challenging and time-consuming. Do your future self a favor, and catalog the next steps for your next session. This allows you to pick back up from that point instead of having to spin up all the context into memory just to piece together where you were.
item.content:encoded:
Getting spun up on a topic can be challenging and time-consuming. Do your future self a favor, and catalog the next steps for your next session. This allows you to pick back up from that point instead of having to spin up all the context into memory just to piece together where you were.

Don’t Start from Scratch

References

item.title: Amethyst
item.description: Tips When using an app and you want some of it’s windows to be floated (aka, not managed by Amethyst) you can specify the window’s title. Often times the types of windows you would like to be floated don’t have a visible title and it can be a chore to detemine it’s title.
item.content:encoded:
Tips

  • When using an app and you want some of it’s windows to be floated (aka, not managed by Amethyst) you can specify the window’s title. Often times the types of windows you would like to be floated don’t have a visible title and it can be a chore to detemine it’s title. This Applescript will give you all the titles of active windows:
1
2
3
4
5

tell application "System Events"

set allWindows to name of window of processes whose visible is true

end tell

item.title: You need a zero friction capture for your reading list
item.description: For me, I use whatever task inbox I am using ( Inboxes only work if you trust how they’re drained). Yes, it would be nice to have a dedicated app that handles the nuances of reading lists, but the more important thing for me is that these things are visible alongside the other tasks I’m prioritizing and taking on as everything you do ultimately pulls from the same time bucket.
item.content:encoded: For me, I use whatever task inbox I am using ( Inboxes only work if you trust how they’re drained). Yes, it would be nice to have a dedicated app that handles the nuances of reading lists, but the more important thing for me is that these things are visible alongside the other tasks I’m prioritizing and taking on as everything you do ultimately pulls from the same time bucket.

item.title: Ignorance can be a benefit
item.description: Biologist and Nobel Prize winner Sydney Brenner on innovative thinking: >“I strongly believe that the only way to encourage innovation is to give it to the young. The young have a great advantage in that they are ignorant.
item.content:encoded:
Biologist and Nobel Prize winner Sydney Brenner on innovative thinking: >“I strongly believe that the only way to encourage innovation is to give it to the young. The young have a great advantage in that they are ignorant. Because I think ignorance in science is very important. If you’re like me and you know too much you can’t try new things. I always work in fields of which I’m totally ignorant.”

This was definitely true for me at Dorsata. We approached many things in healthcare purposefully different because we were ignorant to how things have traditionally been done. Of course this made many things more painful, but it also led to a differentiated approach and is the source of much of our success.

item.title: SurfingKeys
item.description: Tried out on 2022-04-29, but it seemed too complicated and not a big enough upgrade over Vimium to warrant relearning a bunch of muscle memory.
item.content:encoded: Tried out on 2022-04-29, but it seemed too complicated and not a big enough upgrade over Vimium to warrant relearning a bunch of muscle memory.
